Matthew-1-1: The Family History of Jesus the Messiah(A) 1 This is the family history of Jesus the Messiah. He came from the family of David, who was from the family of Abraham.
Matthew-1-2: 2 Abraham was the father of Isaac. Isaac was the father of Jacob. Jacob was the father of Judah and his brothers.
Matthew-1-3: 3 Judah was the father of Perez and Zerah. (Their mother was Tamar.) Perez was the father of Hezron. Hezron was the father of Ram.
Matthew-1-4: 4 Ram was the father of Amminadab. Amminadab was the father of Nahshon. Nahshon was the father of Salmon.
Matthew-1-5: 5 Salmon was the father of Boaz. (His mother was Rahab.) Boaz was the father of Obed. (His mother was Ruth.) Obed was the father of Jesse.
Matthew-1-6: 6 Jesse was the father of King David. David was the father of Solomon. (His mother had been Uriah’s wife.)
Matthew-1-7: 7 Solomon was the father of Rehoboam. Rehoboam was the father of Abijah. Abijah was the father of Asa.
Matthew-1-8: 8 Asa was the father of Jehoshaphat. Jehoshaphat was the father of Jehoram. Jehoram was the father of Uzziah.
Matthew-1-9: 9 Uzziah was the father of Jotham. Jotham was the father of Ahaz. Ahaz was the father of Hezekiah.
Matthew-1-10: 10 Hezekiah was the father of Manasseh. Manasseh was the father of Amon. Amon was the father of Josiah.
Matthew-1-11: 11 Josiah was the grandfather of Jehoiachin[a] and his brothers, who lived during the time that the people were taken away to Babylon.
Matthew-1-12: 12 After they were taken to Babylon: Jehoiachin was the father of Shealtiel. Shealtiel was the grandfather of Zerubbabel.
Matthew-1-13: 13 Zerubbabel was the father of Abiud. Abiud was the father of Eliakim. Eliakim was the father of Azor.
Matthew-1-14: 14 Azor was the father of Zadok. Zadok was the father of Achim. Achim was the father of Eliud.
Matthew-1-15: 15 Eliud was the father of Eleazar. Eleazar was the father of Matthan. Matthan was the father of Jacob.
Matthew-1-16: 16 Jacob was the father of Joseph. Joseph was the husband of Mary, and Mary was the mother of Jesus, who is called the Messiah.
Matthew-1-17: 17 So there were fourteen generations from Abraham to David. There were also fourteen generations from David until the people were taken away to Babylon. And there were fourteen more from the time the people were taken to Babylon until the Messiah was born.
Matthew-1-18: The Birth of Jesus the Messiah(B) 18 This is how the birth of Jesus the Messiah happened. His mother Mary was engaged to marry Joseph. But before they married, he learned that she was expecting a baby. (She was pregnant by the power of the Holy Spirit.)
Matthew-1-19: 19 Mary’s husband, Joseph, was a good man. He did not want to cause her public disgrace, so he planned to divorce her secretly.
Matthew-1-20: 20 But after Joseph thought about this, an angel from the Lord came to him in a dream. The angel said, “Joseph, son of David, don’t be afraid to accept Mary to be your wife. The baby inside her is from the Holy Spirit.
Matthew-1-21: 21 She will give birth to a son. You will name him Jesus.[b] Give him that name because he will save his people from their sins.”
Matthew-1-22: 22 All this happened to make clear the full meaning of what the Lord said through the prophet:
Matthew-1-23: 23 “The virgin will be pregnant and will give birth to a son. They will name him Immanuel.”[c] (Immanuel means “God with us.”)
Matthew-1-24: 24 When Joseph woke up, he did what the Lord’s angel told him to do. He married Mary.
Matthew-1-25: 25 But Joseph did not have sexual relations with her until her son was born. And he named him Jesus.
Matthew-2-1: Wise Men Come to Visit Jesus 2 Jesus was born in the town of Bethlehem in Judea during the time when Herod was king. After Jesus was born, some wise men from the east came to Jerusalem.
Matthew-2-2: 2 They asked people, “Where is the child who has been born to be the king of the Jews? We saw the star that shows he was born. We saw it rise in the sky in the east and have come to worship him.”
Matthew-2-3: 3 When King Herod heard about this, it upset him as well as everyone else in Jerusalem.
Matthew-2-4: 4 Herod called a meeting of all the leading Jewish priests and teachers of the law. He asked them where the Messiah would be born.
Matthew-2-5: 5 They answered, “In the town of Bethlehem in Judea, just as the prophet wrote:
Matthew-2-6: 6 ‘Bethlehem, in the land of Judah,     you are important among the rulers of Judah. you are important among the rulers of Judah. Yes, a ruler will come from you,     and that ruler will lead Israel, my people.’” (A) and that ruler will lead Israel, my people.’” (A)
Matthew-2-7: 7 Then Herod had a private meeting with the wise men from the east. He learned from them the exact time they first saw the star.
Matthew-2-8: 8 Then he sent them to Bethlehem. He said, “Go and look carefully for the child. When you find him, come tell me. Then I can go worship him too.”
Matthew-2-9: 9 After the wise men heard the king, they left. They saw the same star they had seen in the east, and they followed it. The star went before them until it stopped above the place where the child was.
Matthew-2-10: 10 They were very happy and excited to see the star.
Matthew-2-11: 11 The wise men came to the house where the child was with his mother Mary. They bowed down and worshiped him. Then they opened the boxes of gifts they had brought for him. They gave him treasures of gold, frankincense, and myrrh.
Matthew-2-12: 12 But God warned the wise men in a dream not to go back to Herod. So they went home to their own country a different way.
Matthew-2-13: Jesus’ Parents Take Him to Egypt 13 After the wise men left, an angel from the Lord came to Joseph in a dream. The angel said, “Get up! Take the child with his mother and escape to Egypt. Herod wants to kill the child and will soon start looking for him. Stay in Egypt until I tell you to come back.”
Matthew-2-14: 14 So Joseph got ready and left for Egypt with the child and the mother. They left during the night.
Matthew-2-15: 15 Joseph stayed in Egypt until Herod died. This gave full meaning to what the Lord said through the prophet: “I called my son to come out of Egypt.”[a]
Matthew-2-16: Herod Kills the Baby Boys in Bethlehem 16 Herod saw that the wise men had fooled him, and he was very angry. So he gave an order to kill all the baby boys in Bethlehem and the whole area around Bethlehem. Herod had learned from the wise men the time the baby was born. It was now two years from that time. So he said to kill all the boys who were two years old and younger.
Matthew-2-17: 17 This gave full meaning to what God said through the prophet Jeremiah:
Matthew-2-18: 18 “A sound was heard in Ramah—     bitter crying and great sadness. bitter crying and great sadness. Rachel cries for her children,     and she cannot be comforted, and she cannot be comforted,     because her children are gone.” (B) because her children are gone.” (B)
Matthew-2-19: Joseph and Mary Return From Egypt 19 While Joseph was in Egypt, Herod died. An angel from the Lord came to Joseph in a dream
Matthew-2-20: 20 and said, “Get up! Take the child with his mother and go to Israel. Those who were trying to kill the child are now dead.”
Matthew-2-21: 21 So Joseph took the child and the mother and went to Israel.
Matthew-2-22: 22 But he heard that Archelaus was now king in Judea. Archelaus became king when his father Herod died. So Joseph was afraid to go there. Then, after being warned in a dream, he went away to the area of Galilee.
Matthew-2-23: 23 He went to a town called Nazareth and lived there. This gave full meaning to what God said through the prophets. God said the Messiah[b] would be called a Nazarene.[c]
Matthew-3-1: John Prepares the Way for Jesus(A) 3 When it was the right time, John the Baptizer began telling people a message from God. This was out in the desert area of Judea.
Matthew-3-2: 2 John said, “Change your hearts and lives, because God’s kingdom is now very near.[a]”
Matthew-3-3: 3 John is the one Isaiah the prophet was talking about when he said, “There is someone shouting in the desert: ‘Prepare the way for the Lord.     Make the road straight for him.’” (B) Make the road straight for him.’” (B)
Matthew-3-4: 4 John’s clothes were made from camel’s hair, and he had a leather belt around his waist. For food, he ate locusts and wild honey.
Matthew-3-5: 5 People came to John from Jerusalem and the rest of Judea and from all the areas along the Jordan River.
Matthew-3-6: 6 They confessed the bad things they had done, and John baptized them in the Jordan.
Matthew-3-7: 7 Many Pharisees and Sadducees came to where John was baptizing people. When John saw them, he said, “You are all snakes! Who warned you to run from God’s judgment that is coming?
Matthew-3-8: 8 Change your hearts! And show by the way you live that you have changed.
Matthew-3-9: 9 I know what you are thinking. You want to say, ‘but Abraham is our father!’ That means nothing. I tell you, God could make children for Abraham from these rocks.
Matthew-3-10: 10 The ax is now ready to cut down the trees.[b] Every tree that does not produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire.
Matthew-3-11: 11 “I baptize you with water to show that you have changed your hearts and lives. But there is someone coming later who is able to do more than I can. I am not good enough to be the slave who takes off his sandals. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire.
Matthew-3-12: 12 He will come ready to clean the grain.[c] He will separate the good grain from the straw, and he will put the good part into his barn. Then he will burn the useless part with a fire that cannot be stopped.”
Matthew-3-13: Jesus Is Baptized by John(C) 13 Then Jesus came from Galilee to the Jordan River. He came to John, wanting John to baptize him.
Matthew-3-14: 14 But John tried to stop him. John said, “Why do you come to me to be baptized? I should be baptized by you!”
Matthew-3-15: 15 Jesus answered, “Let it be this way for now. We should do whatever God says is right.” Then John agreed.
Matthew-3-16: 16 So Jesus was baptized. As soon as he came up out of the water, the sky opened, and he saw God’s Spirit coming down on him like a dove.
Matthew-3-17: 17 A voice from heaven said, “This is my Son, the one I love. I am very pleased with him.”
Matthew-4-1: The Temptation of Jesus(A) 4 Then the Spirit led Jesus into the desert. He was taken there to be tempted by the devil.
Matthew-4-2: 2 Jesus ate nothing for 40 days and nights. After this, he was very hungry.
Matthew-4-3: 3 The devil[a] came to tempt him and said, “If you are the Son of God, tell these rocks to become bread.”
Matthew-4-4: 4 Jesus answered him, “The Scriptures say, ‘It is not just bread that keeps people alive.     Their lives depend on what God says.’” (B) Their lives depend on what God says.’” (B)
Matthew-4-5: 5 Then the devil led Jesus to the holy city of Jerusalem and put him on a high place at the edge of the Temple area.
Matthew-4-6: 6 He said to Jesus, “If you are the Son of God, jump off, because the Scriptures say, ‘God will command his angels to help you,     and their hands will catch you, and their hands will catch you, so that you will not hit your foot on a rock.’” (C)

Matthew-4-8: 8 Then the devil led Jesus to the top of a very high mountain and showed him all the kingdoms of the world and all the wonderful things in them.
Matthew-4-9: 9 The devil said, “If you will bow down and worship me, I will give you all these things.”
Matthew-4-10: 10 Jesus said to him, “Get away from me, Satan! The Scriptures say, ‘You must worship the Lord your God.     Serve only him!’” (D) Serve only him!’” (D)
Matthew-4-11: 11 So the devil left him. Then some angels came to Jesus and helped him.
Matthew-4-12: Jesus Begins His Work in Galilee(E) 12 Jesus heard that John was put in prison, so he went back to Galilee.
Matthew-4-13: 13 But he did not stay in Nazareth. He went to live in Capernaum, a town near Lake Galilee in the area near Zebulun and Naphtali.
Matthew-4-14: 14 He did this to give full meaning to what the prophet Isaiah said:
Matthew-4-15: 15 “Listen, land of Zebulun and land of Naphtali,     lands by the road that goes to the sea, the area past the Jordan River— lands by the road that goes to the sea, the area past the Jordan River—     Galilee, where those from other nations live. Galilee, where those from other nations live.
Matthew-4-16: 16 The people who live in spiritual darkness     have seen a great light. have seen a great light. The light has shined for those     who live in the land that is as dark as a grave.” (F) who live in the land that is as dark as a grave.” (F)
Matthew-4-17: 17 From that time Jesus began to tell people his message: “Change your hearts and lives, because God’s kingdom is now very near.[c]”
Matthew-4-18: Jesus Chooses Some Followers(G) 18 As Jesus was walking by Lake Galilee, he saw two brothers, Simon (called Peter) and Simon’s brother Andrew. These brothers were fishermen, and they were fishing in the lake with a net.
Matthew-4-19: 19 Jesus said to them, “Come, follow me, and I will make you a different kind of fishermen. You will bring in people, not fish.”
Matthew-4-20: 20 Simon and Andrew immediately left their nets and followed him.
Matthew-4-21: 21 Jesus continued walking by Lake Galilee. He saw two other brothers, James and John, the sons of Zebedee. They were in a boat with their father Zebedee. They were preparing their nets to catch fish. Jesus told the brothers to come with him.
Matthew-4-22: 22 So they immediately left the boat and their father, and they followed Jesus.
Matthew-4-23: Jesus Teaches and Heals the People(H) 23 Jesus went everywhere in the country of Galilee. He taught in the synagogues and told the Good News about God’s kingdom. And he healed all the people’s diseases and sicknesses.
Matthew-4-24: 24 The news about Jesus spread all over Syria, and people brought to him all those who were sick. They were suffering from different kinds of diseases and pain. Some had demons inside them, some suffered from seizures, and some were paralyzed. Jesus healed them all.
Matthew-4-25: 25 Large crowds followed him—people from Galilee, the Ten Towns, Jerusalem, Judea, and the area across the Jordan River.
Matthew-5-1: Jesus Teaches the People(A) 5 When Jesus saw the crowds of people there, he went up on a hill and sat down. His followers came and sat next to him.
Matthew-5-2: 2 Then Jesus began teaching the people. He said,
Matthew-5-3: 3 “Great blessings belong to those who know they are spiritually in need.[a]     God’s kingdom belongs to them. God’s kingdom belongs to them.
Matthew-5-4: 4 Great blessings belong to those who are sad now.     God will comfort them. God will comfort them.
Matthew-5-5: 5 Great blessings belong to those who are humble.     They will be given the land God promised.[b] They will be given the land God promised.[b]
Matthew-5-6: 6 Great blessings belong to those who want to do right more than anything else.[c]     God will fully satisfy them. God will fully satisfy them.
Matthew-5-7: 7 Great blessings belong to those who show mercy to others.     Mercy will be given to them. Mercy will be given to them.
Matthew-5-8: 8 Great blessings belong to those whose thoughts are pure.     They will be with God. They will be with God.
Matthew-5-9: 9 Great blessings belong to those who work to bring peace.     God will call them his sons and daughters. God will call them his sons and daughters.
Matthew-5-10: 10 Great blessings belong to those who suffer persecution for doing what is right.     God’s kingdom belongs to them. God’s kingdom belongs to them.
Matthew-5-11: 11 “People will insult you and hurt you. They will lie and say all kinds of evil things about you because you follow me. But when they do that, know that great blessings belong to you.
Matthew-5-12: 12 Be happy about it. Be very glad because you have a great reward waiting for you in heaven. People did these same bad things to the prophets who lived before you.
Matthew-5-13: You Are Like Salt and Light(B) 13 “You are the salt of the earth. But if the salt loses its taste, it cannot be made salty again. Salt is useless if it loses its salty taste. It will be thrown out where people will just walk on it.
Matthew-5-14: 14 “You are the light that shines for the world to see. You are like a city built on a hill that cannot be hidden.
Matthew-5-15: 15 People don’t hide a lamp under a bowl. They put it on a lampstand. Then the light shines for everyone in the house.
Matthew-5-16: 16 In the same way, you should be a light for other people. Live so that they will see the good things you do and praise your Father in heaven.
Matthew-5-17: Jesus and the Old Testament Writings 17 “Don’t think that I have come to destroy the Law of Moses or the teaching of the prophets. I have come not to destroy their teachings but to give full meaning to them.
Matthew-5-18: 18 I assure you that nothing will disappear from the law until heaven and earth are gone. The law will not lose even the smallest letter or the smallest part of a letter until it has all been done.
Matthew-5-19: 19 “A person should obey every command in the law, even one that does not seem important. Whoever refuses to obey any command and teaches others not to obey it will be the least important in God’s kingdom. But whoever obeys the law and teaches others to obey it will be great in God’s kingdom.
Matthew-5-20: 20 I tell you that you must do better than the teachers of the law and the Pharisees. If you are not more pleasing to God than they are, you will never enter God’s kingdom.
Matthew-5-21: Jesus Teaches About Anger 21 “You have heard that it was said to our people long ago, ‘You must not murder anyone.[d] Any person who commits murder will be judged.’
Matthew-5-22: 22 But I tell you, don’t be angry with anyone. If you are angry with others, you will be judged. And if you insult someone, you will be judged by the high court. And if you call someone a fool, you will be in danger of the fire of hell.
Matthew-5-23: 23 “So, what if you are offering your gift at the altar and remember that someone has something against you?
Matthew-5-24: 24 Leave your gift there and go make peace with that person. Then come and offer your gift.
Matthew-5-25: 25 “If anyone wants to take you to court, make friends with them quickly. Try to do that before you get to the court. If you don’t, they might hand you over to the judge. And the judge will hand you over to a guard, who will throw you into jail.
Matthew-5-26: 26 I assure you that you will not leave there until you have paid everything you owe.
Matthew-5-27: Jesus Teaches About Sexual Sin 27 “You have heard that it was said, ‘You must not commit adultery.’[e]
Matthew-5-28: 28 But I tell you that if a man looks at a woman and wants to sin sexually with her, he has already committed that sin with her in his mind.
Matthew-5-29: 29 If your right eye makes you sin, take it out and throw it away. It is better to lose one part of your body than to have your whole body thrown into hell.
Matthew-5-30: 30 If your right hand makes you sin, cut it off and throw it away. It is better to lose one part of your body than for your whole body to go into hell.
Matthew-5-31: Jesus Teaches About Divorce(C) 31 “It was also said, ‘Any man who divorces his wife must give her a written notice of divorce.’[f]
Matthew-5-32: 32 But I tell you that any man who divorces his wife, except for the problem of sexual sin, is causing his wife to be guilty of adultery. And whoever marries a divorced woman is guilty of adultery.
Matthew-5-33: Jesus Teaches About Making Promises 33 “You have heard that it was said to our people long ago, ‘When you make a vow, you must not break your promise. Keep the vows that you make to the Lord.’[g]
Matthew-5-34: 34 But I tell you, when you make a promise, don’t try to make it stronger with a vow. Don’t make a vow using the name of heaven, because heaven is God’s throne.
Matthew-5-35: 35 Don’t make a vow using the name of the earth, because the earth belongs to him.[h] Don’t make a vow using the name of Jerusalem, because it also belongs to him, the great King.
Matthew-5-36: 36 And don’t even say that your own head is proof that you will keep your promise. You cannot make one hair on your head white or black.
Matthew-5-37: 37 Say only ‘yes’ if you mean ‘yes,’ and say only ‘no’ if you mean ‘no.’ If you say more than that, it is from the Evil One.
Matthew-5-38: Jesus Teaches About Fighting Back(D) 38 “You have heard that it was said, ‘An eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth.’[i]
Matthew-5-39: 39 But I tell you, don’t fight back against someone who wants to do harm to you. If they hit you on the right cheek, let them hit the other cheek too.
Matthew-5-40: 40 If anyone wants to sue you in court and take your shirt, let them have your coat too.
Matthew-5-41: 41 If a soldier forces you to walk with him one mile,[j] go with him two.
Matthew-5-42: 42 Give to anyone who asks you for something. Don’t refuse to give to anyone who wants to borrow from you.
Matthew-5-43: Love Your Enemies(E) 43 “You have heard that it was said, ‘Love your neighbor[k] and hate your enemy.’
Matthew-5-44: 44 But I tell you, love your enemies. Pray for those who treat you badly.
Matthew-5-45: 45 If you do this, you will be children who are truly like your Father in heaven. He lets the sun rise for all people, whether they are good or bad. He sends rain to those who do right and to those who do wrong.
Matthew-5-46: 46 If you love only those who love you, why should you get a reward for that? Even the tax collectors do that.
Matthew-5-47: 47 And if you are nice only to your friends, you are no better than anyone else. Even the people who don’t know God are nice to their friends.
Matthew-5-48: 48 What I am saying is that you must be perfect, just as your Father in heaven is perfect.
Matthew-6-1: Jesus Teaches About Giving 6 “Be careful! When you do something good, don’t do it in front of others so that they will see you. If you do that, you will have no reward from your Father in heaven.
Matthew-6-2: 2 “When you give to those who are poor, don’t announce that you are giving. Don’t be like the hypocrites. When they are in the synagogues and on the streets, they blow trumpets before they give so that people will see them. They want everyone to praise them. The truth is, that’s all the reward they will get.
Matthew-6-3: 3 So when you give to the poor, don’t let anyone know what you are doing.[a]
Matthew-6-4: 4 Your giving should be done in private. Your Father can see what is done in private, and he will reward you.
Matthew-6-5: Jesus Teaches About Prayer(A) 5 “When you pray, don’t be like the hypocrites. They love to stand in the synagogues and on the street corners and pray loudly. They want people to see them. The truth is, that’s all the reward they will get.
Matthew-6-6: 6 But when you pray, you should go into your room and close the door. Then pray to your Father. He is there in that private place. He can see what is done in private, and he will reward you.
Matthew-6-7: 7 “And when you pray, don’t be like the people who don’t know God. They say the same things again and again. They think that if they say it enough, their god will hear them.
Matthew-6-8: 8 Don’t be like them. Your Father knows what you need before you ask him.
Matthew-6-9: 9 So this is how you should pray: ‘Our Father in heaven,     we pray that your name will always be kept holy. we pray that your name will always be kept holy.
Matthew-6-10: 10 We pray that your kingdom will come—     that what you want will be done here on earth, the same as in heaven. that what you want will be done here on earth, the same as in heaven.
Matthew-6-11: 11 Give us the food we need for today.
Matthew-6-12: 12 Forgive our sins,     just as we have forgiven those who did wrong to us. just as we have forgiven those who did wrong to us.
Matthew-6-13: 13 Don’t let us be tempted,     but save us from the Evil One.’[b] but save us from the Evil One.’[b]
Matthew-6-14: 14 Yes, if you forgive others for the wrongs they do to you, then your Father in heaven will also forgive your wrongs.
Matthew-6-15: 15 But if you don’t forgive others, then your Father in heaven will not forgive the wrongs you do.
Matthew-6-16: Jesus Teaches About Fasting 16 “When you fast, don’t make yourselves look sad like the hypocrites. They put a look of suffering on their faces so that people will see they are fasting. The truth is, that’s all the reward they will get.
Matthew-6-17: 17 So when you fast, wash your face and make yourself look nice.
Matthew-6-18: 18 Then no one will know you are fasting, except your Father, who is with you even in private. He can see what is done in private, and he will reward you.
Matthew-6-19: You Cannot Serve Two Masters(B) 19 “Don’t save treasures for yourselves here on earth. Moths and rust will destroy them. And thieves can break into your house and steal them.
Matthew-6-20: 20 Instead, save your treasures in heaven, where they cannot be destroyed by moths or rust and where thieves cannot break in and steal them.
Matthew-6-21: 21 Your heart will be where your treasure is.
Matthew-6-22: 22 “The only source of light for the body is the eye. If you look at people and want to help them, you will be full of light.
Matthew-6-23: 23 But if you look at people in a selfish way, you will be full of darkness. And if the only light you have is really darkness, you have the worst kind of darkness.[c]
Matthew-6-24: 24 “You cannot serve two masters at the same time. You will hate one and love the other, or you will be loyal to one and not care about the other. You cannot serve God and Money[d] at the same time.
Matthew-6-25: Put God’s Kingdom First(C) 25 “So I tell you, don’t worry about the things you need to live—what you will eat, drink, or wear. Life is more important than food, and the body is more important than what you put on it.
Matthew-6-26: 26 Look at the birds. They don’t plant, harvest, or save food in barns, but your heavenly Father feeds them. Don’t you know you are worth much more than they are?
Matthew-6-27: 27 You cannot add any time to your life by worrying about it.
Matthew-6-28: 28 “And why do you worry about clothes? Look at the wildflowers in the field. See how they grow. They don’t work or make clothes for themselves.
Matthew-6-29: 29 But I tell you that even Solomon, the great and rich king, was not dressed as beautifully as one of these flowers.
Matthew-6-30: 30 If God makes what grows in the field so beautiful, what do you think he will do for you? It’s just grass—one day it’s alive, and the next day someone throws it into a fire. But God cares enough to make it beautiful. Surely he will do much more for you. Your faith is so small!
Matthew-6-31: 31 “Don’t worry and say, ‘What will we eat?’ or ‘What will we drink?’ or ‘What will we wear?’
Matthew-6-32: 32 That’s what those people who don’t know God are always thinking about. Don’t worry, because your Father in heaven knows that you need all these things.
Matthew-6-33: 33 What you should want most is God’s kingdom and doing what he wants you to do. Then he will give you all these other things you need.
Matthew-6-34: 34 So don’t worry about tomorrow. Each day has enough trouble of its own. Tomorrow will have its own worries.
Matthew-7-1: Be Careful About Criticizing Others(A) 7 “Don’t judge others, and God will not judge you.
Matthew-7-2: 2 If you judge others, you will be judged the same way you judge them. God will treat you the same way you treat others.
Matthew-7-3: 3 “Why do you notice the small piece of dust that is in your friend’s eye, but you don’t notice the big piece of wood that is in your own?
Matthew-7-4: 4 Why do you say to your friend, ‘Let me take that piece of dust out of your eye’? Look at yourself first! You still have that big piece of wood in your own eye.
Matthew-7-5: 5 You are a hypocrite! First, take the wood out of your own eye. Then you will see clearly to get the dust out of your friend’s eye.

Matthew-12-23: 23 All the people were amazed at what Jesus did. They said, “Maybe he is the promised Son of David!”

Matthew-12-46: Jesus’ Followers Are His True Family(H) 46 While Jesus was talking to the people, his mother and brothers stood outside. They wanted to talk to him.

Matthew-13-1: A Story About a Farmer Sowing Seed(A) 13 That same day Jesus went out of the house and sat by the lake.
Matthew-13-2: 2 A large crowd gathered around him. So he got into a boat and sat down. All the people stayed on the shore.
Matthew-13-3: 3 Then Jesus used stories to teach them many things. He told them this story: “A farmer went out to sow seed.
Matthew-13-4: 4 While he was scattering the seed, some of it fell by the road. The birds came and ate all that seed.
Matthew-13-5: 5 Other seed fell on rocky ground, where there was not enough dirt. It grew very fast there, because the soil was not deep.
Matthew-13-6: 6 But when the sun rose, it burned the plants. The plants died because they did not have deep roots.
Matthew-13-7: 7 Some other seed fell among thorny weeds. The weeds grew and stopped the good plants from growing.
Matthew-13-8: 8 But some of the seed fell on good ground. There it grew and made grain. Some plants made 100 times more grain, some 60 times more, and some 30 times more.

Matthew-13-11: 11 Jesus answered, “Only you can know the secret truths about God’s kingdom. Those other people cannot know these secret truths.

Matthew-13-13: 13 This is why I use these stories to teach the people: They see, but they don’t really see. They hear, but they don’t really hear or understand.
Matthew-13-14: 14 So they show that what Isaiah said about them is true: ‘You people will listen and listen,     but you will not understand. but you will not understand. You will look and look,     but you will not really see. but you will not really see.

Matthew-13-16: 16 But God has blessed you. You understand what you see with your eyes. And you understand what you hear with your ears.
Matthew-13-17: 17 I can assure you, many prophets and godly people wanted to see what you now see. But they did not see it. And many prophets and godly people wanted to hear what you now hear. But they did not hear it.
Matthew-13-18: Jesus Explains the Story About Seed(D) 18 “So listen to the meaning of that story about the farmer:
Matthew-13-19: 19 “What about the seed that fell by the path? That is like the people who hear the teaching about God’s kingdom but do not understand it. The Evil One comes and takes away what was planted in their hearts.
Matthew-13-20: 20 “And what about the seed that fell on rocky ground? That is like the people who hear the teaching and quickly and gladly accept it.
Matthew-13-21: 21 But they do not let the teaching go deep into their lives. They keep it only a short time. As soon as trouble or persecution comes because of the teaching they accepted, they give up.
Matthew-13-22: 22 “And what about the seed that fell among the thorny weeds? That is like the people who hear the teaching but let worries about this life and love for money stop it from growing. So it does not produce a crop in their lives.
Matthew-13-23: 23 “But what about the seed that fell on the good ground? That is like the people who hear the teaching and understand it. They grow and produce a good crop, sometimes 100 times more, sometimes 60 times more, and sometimes 30 times more.”
Matthew-13-24: A Story About Wheat and Weeds 24 Then Jesus used another story to teach them. Jesus said, “God’s kingdom is like a man who planted good seed in his field.
Matthew-13-25: 25 That night, while everyone was asleep, the man’s enemy came and planted weeds among the wheat and then left.
Matthew-13-26: 26 Later, the wheat grew, and heads of grain grew on the plants. But at the same time the weeds also grew.
Matthew-13-27: 27 Then the man’s servants came to him and said, ‘You planted good seed in your field. Where did the weeds come from?’
Matthew-13-28: 28 “The man answered, ‘An enemy planted weeds.’ “The servants asked, ‘Do you want us to go and pull up the weeds?’

Matthew-13-31: What Is God’s Kingdom Like?(E) 31 Then Jesus told the people another story: “God’s kingdom is like a mustard seed that a man plants in his field.
Matthew-13-32: 32 It is the smallest of all seeds. But when it grows, it is the largest of all garden plants. It becomes a tree big enough for the birds to come and make nests in its branches.”
Matthew-13-33: 33 Then Jesus told them another story: “God’s kingdom is like yeast that a woman mixes into a big bowl of flour to make bread. The yeast makes all the dough rise.”
Matthew-13-34: 34 Jesus used stories to tell all these things to the people. He always used stories to teach them.
Matthew-13-35: 35 This was to make clear the full meaning of what the prophet said: “I will speak using stories;     I will tell things that have been secrets since the world was made.” (F) I will tell things that have been secrets since the world was made.” (F)
Matthew-13-36: Jesus Explains a Hard Story 36 Then Jesus left the people and went into the house. His followers came to him and said, “Explain to us the meaning of the story about the weeds in the field.”
Matthew-13-37: 37 He answered, “The man who planted the good seed in the field is the Son of Man.
Matthew-13-38: 38 The field is the world. The good seed are the people in God’s kingdom. The weeds are the people who belong to the Evil One.
Matthew-13-39: 39 And the enemy who planted the bad seed is the devil. The harvest is the end of time. And the workers who gather are God’s angels.

Matthew-13-41: 41 The Son of Man will send his angels, and they will find the people who cause sin and all those who do evil. The angels will take those people out of his kingdom.

Matthew-13-44: Stories About a Treasure and a Pearl 44 “God’s kingdom is like a treasure hidden in a field. One day a man found the treasure. He hid it again and was so happy that he went and sold everything he owned and bought the field.

Matthew-13-46: 46 One day he found a very fine pearl. He went and sold everything he had to buy it.

Matthew-13-53: Jesus Goes to His Hometown(G) 53 When Jesus finished teaching with these stories, he left there.

Matthew-14-1: Herod Thinks Jesus Is John the Baptizer(A) 14 About that time, Herod, the ruler of Galilee, heard what the people were saying about Jesus.

Matthew-14-7: 7 So he promised that he would give her anything she wanted.

Matthew-14-13: Jesus Feeds More Than 5000(B) 13 When Jesus heard what happened to John, he left in a boat. He went alone to a place where no one lived. But the people heard that Jesus had left. So they left their towns and followed him. They went by land to the same place he went.

Matthew-15-37: 37 All the people ate until they were full. After this, the followers filled seven baskets with the pieces of food that were not eaten.

Matthew-16-13: Peter Says Jesus Is the Messiah(C) 13 Jesus went to the area of Caesarea Philippi. He said to his followers, “Who do people say I am[b]?”

Matthew-16-26: 26 It is worth nothing for you to have the whole world if you yourself are lost. You could never pay enough to buy back your life.
Matthew-16-27: 27 The Son of Man will come again with his Father’s glory and with his angels. And he will reward everyone for what they have done.
Matthew-16-28: 28 Believe me when I say that there are some people standing here who will see the Son of Man coming with his kingdom before they die.”
Matthew-17-1: Jesus Is Seen With Moses and Elijah(A) 17 Six days later, Jesus took Peter, James, and John the brother of James and went up on a high mountain. They were all alone there.
Matthew-17-2: 2 While these followers watched him, Jesus was changed. His face became bright like the sun, and his clothes became white as light.
Matthew-17-3: 3 Then two men were there, talking with him. They were Moses and Elijah.
Matthew-17-4: 4 Peter said to Jesus, “Lord, it is good that we are here. If you want, I will put three tents here—one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.”
Matthew-17-5: 5 While Peter was talking, a bright cloud came over them. A voice came from the cloud and said, “This is my Son, the one I love. I am very pleased with him. Obey him!”
Matthew-17-6: 6 The followers with Jesus heard this voice. They were very afraid, so they fell to the ground.
Matthew-17-7: 7 But Jesus came to them and touched them. He said, “Stand up. Don’t be afraid.”
Matthew-17-8: 8 The followers looked up, and they saw that Jesus was now alone.
Matthew-17-9: 9 As Jesus and the followers were coming down the mountain, he gave them this command: “Don’t tell anyone about what you saw on the mountain. Wait until the Son of Man has been raised from death. Then you can tell people about what you saw.”
Matthew-17-10: 10 The followers asked Jesus, “Why do the teachers of the law say that Elijah must come[a] before the Messiah comes?”
Matthew-17-11: 11 Jesus answered, “They are right to say Elijah is coming. And it is true that Elijah will make all things the way they should be.
Matthew-17-12: 12 But I tell you, Elijah has already come. People did not know who he was, and they treated him badly, doing whatever they wanted to do. It is the same with the Son of Man. Those same people will make the Son of Man suffer.”
Matthew-17-13: 13 Then the followers understood that when Jesus said Elijah, he was really talking about John the Baptizer.
Matthew-17-14: Jesus Frees a Boy From an Evil Spirit(B) 14 Jesus and the followers went back to the people. A man came to Jesus and bowed before him.
Matthew-17-15: 15 The man said, “Lord, be kind to my son. He suffers so much from the seizures he has. He often falls into the fire or into the water.
Matthew-17-16: 16 I brought him to your followers, but they could not heal him.”
Matthew-17-17: 17 Jesus answered, “You people today have no faith. Your lives are so wrong! How long must I stay with you? How long must I continue to be patient with you? Bring the boy here.”
Matthew-17-18: 18 Jesus gave a strong command to the demon inside the boy. The demon came out of the boy, and the boy was healed.
Matthew-17-19: 19 Then the followers came to Jesus alone. They said, “We tried to force the demon out of the boy, but we could not. Why were we not able to make the demon go out?”
Matthew-17-20: 20 Jesus answered, “You were not able to make the demon go out, because your faith is too small. Believe me when I tell you, if your faith is only as big as a mustard seed you can say to this mountain, ‘Move from here to there,’ and it will move. You will be able to do anything.”
Matthew-17-22: Jesus Talks About His Death(C) 22 Later, the followers met together in Galilee. Jesus said to them, “The Son of Man will be handed over to the control of other men,
Matthew-17-23: 23 who will kill him. But on the third day he will be raised from death.” The followers were very sad to hear that Jesus would be killed.
Matthew-17-24: Jesus Teaches About Paying Taxes 24 Jesus and his followers went to Capernaum. There the men who collect the two-drachma Temple tax came to Peter and asked, “Does your teacher pay the Temple tax?”
Matthew-17-25: 25 Peter answered, “Yes, he does.” Peter went into the house where Jesus was. Before Peter could speak, Jesus said to him, “The kings on the earth get different kinds of taxes from people. But who are those who pay the taxes? Are they the king’s children? Or do other people pay the taxes? What do you think?”
Matthew-17-26: 26 Peter answered, “The other people pay the taxes.” Jesus said, “Then the children of the king don’t have to pay taxes.
Matthew-17-27: 27 But we don’t want to upset these tax collectors. So do this: Go to the lake and fish. After you catch the first fish, open its mouth. Inside its mouth you will find a four-drachma coin. Take that coin and give it to the tax collectors. That will pay the tax for you and me.”
Matthew-18-1: Who Is the Greatest?(A) 18 About that time the followers came to Jesus and asked, “Who is the greatest in God’s kingdom?”
Matthew-18-2: 2 Jesus called a little child to come to him. He stood the child in front of the followers.
Matthew-18-3: 3 Then he said, “The truth is, you must change your thinking and become like little children. If you don’t do this, you will never enter God’s kingdom.
Matthew-18-4: 4 The greatest person in God’s kingdom is the one who makes himself humble like this child.
Matthew-18-5: 5 “Whoever accepts a little child like this in my name is accepting me.
Matthew-18-6: Jesus Warns About Causes of Sin(B) 6 “If one of these little children believes in me, and someone causes that child to sin, it will be very bad for that person. It would be better for them to have a millstone tied around their neck and be drowned in the deep sea.
Matthew-18-7: 7 I feel sorry for the people in the world because of the things that make people sin. These things must happen, but it will be very bad for anyone who causes them to happen.
Matthew-18-8: 8 “If your hand or your foot makes you sin, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to lose part of your body and have eternal life than to have two hands and two feet and be thrown into the fire that burns forever.
Matthew-18-9: 9 If your eye makes you sin, take it out and throw it away. It is better for you to have only one eye and have eternal life than to have two eyes and be thrown into the fire of hell.
Matthew-18-10: Jesus Uses a Story About a Lost Sheep(C) 10 “Be careful. Don’t think these little children are not important. I tell you that these children have angels in heaven. And those angels are always with my Father in heaven.
Matthew-18-12: 12 “If a man has 100 sheep, but one of the sheep is lost, what will he do? He will leave the other 99 sheep on the hill and go look for the lost sheep. Right?
Matthew-18-13: 13 And if he finds the lost sheep, he is happier about that one sheep than about the 99 sheep that were never lost. I can assure you,
Matthew-18-14: 14 in the same way your Father in heaven does not want any of these little children to be lost.
Matthew-18-15: When Someone Hurts You(D) 15 “If your brother or sister in God’s family does something wrong, go and tell them what they did wrong. Do this when you are alone with them. If they listen to you, then you have helped them to be your brother or sister again.
Matthew-18-16: 16 But if they refuse to listen, go to them again and take one or two people with you. Then there will be two or three people who will be able to tell all that happened.[b]
Matthew-18-17: 17 If they refuse to listen to them, tell the church. And if they refuse to listen to the church, treat them as you would treat someone who does not know God or who is a tax collector.
Matthew-18-18: 18 “I can assure you that when you speak judgment here on earth, it will be God’s judgment. And when you promise forgiveness here on earth, it will be God’s forgiveness.[c]
Matthew-18-19: 19 To say it another way, if two of you on earth agree on anything you pray for, my Father in heaven will do what you ask.
Matthew-18-20: 20 Yes, if two or three people are together believing in me, I am there with them.”
Matthew-18-21: A Story About Forgiveness 21 Then Peter came to Jesus and asked, “Lord, when someone[d] won’t stop doing wrong to me, how many times must I forgive them? Seven times?”
Matthew-18-22: 22 Jesus answered, “I tell you, you must forgive them more than seven times. You must continue to forgive them even if they do wrong to you seventy-seven times.[e]
Matthew-18-23: 23 “So God’s kingdom is like a king who decided to collect the money his servants owed him.
Matthew-18-24: 24 The king began to collect his money. One servant owed him several thousand pounds[f] of silver.
Matthew-18-25: 25 He was not able to pay the money to his master, the king. So the master ordered that he and everything he owned be sold, even his wife and children. The money would be used to pay the king what the servant owed.
Matthew-18-26: 26 “But the servant fell on his knees and begged, ‘Be patient with me. I will pay you everything I owe.’
Matthew-18-27: 27 The master felt sorry for him. So he told the servant he did not have to pay. He let him go free.
Matthew-18-28: 28 “Later, that same servant found another servant who owed him a hundred silver coins. He grabbed him around the neck and said, ‘Pay me the money you owe me!’
Matthew-18-29: 29 “The other servant fell on his knees and begged him, ‘Be patient with me. I will pay you everything I owe.’
Matthew-18-30: 30 “But the first servant refused to be patient. He told the judge that the other servant owed him money, and that servant was put in jail until he could pay everything he owed.
Matthew-18-31: 31 All the other servants saw what happened. They felt very sorry for the man. So they went and told their master everything that happened.
Matthew-18-32: 32 “Then the master called his servant in and said, ‘You evil servant. You begged me to forgive your debt, and I said you did not have to pay anything!
Matthew-18-33: 33 So you should have given that other man who serves with you the same mercy I gave you.’
Matthew-18-34: 34 The master was very angry, so he put the servant in jail to be punished. And he had to stay in jail until he could pay everything he owed.
Matthew-18-35: 35 “This king did the same as my heavenly Father will do to you. You must forgive your brother or sister with all your heart, or my heavenly Father will not forgive you.”
Matthew-19-1: Jesus Teaches About Divorce(A) 19 After Jesus said all these things, he left Galilee. He went into the area of Judea on the other side of the Jordan River.
Matthew-19-2: 2 Many people followed him. Jesus healed the sick people there.
Matthew-19-3: 3 Some Pharisees came to Jesus. They tried to make him say something wrong. They asked him, “Is it right for a man to divorce his wife for any reason he chooses?”
Matthew-19-4: 4 Jesus answered, “Surely you have read this in the Scriptures: When God made the world, ‘he made people male and female.’[a]
Matthew-19-5: 5 And God said, ‘That is why a man will leave his father and mother and be joined to his wife. And the two people will become one.’[b]
Matthew-19-6: 6 So they are no longer two, but one. God has joined them together, so no one should separate them.”
Matthew-19-7: 7 The Pharisees asked, “Then why did Moses give a command allowing a man to divorce his wife by writing a certificate of divorce[c]?”
Matthew-19-8: 8 Jesus answered, “Moses allowed you to divorce your wives because you refused to accept God’s teaching. But divorce was not allowed in the beginning.
Matthew-19-9: 9 I tell you that whoever divorces his wife, except for the problem of sexual sin, and marries another woman is guilty of adultery.”
Matthew-19-10: 10 The followers said to Jesus, “If that is the only reason a man can divorce his wife, it is better not to marry.”
Matthew-19-11: 11 He answered, “This statement is true for some, but not for everyone—only for those who have been given this gift.
Matthew-19-12: 12 There are different reasons why some men don’t marry.[d] Some were born without the ability to produce children. Others were made that way later in life. And others have given up marriage because of God’s kingdom. This is for anyone who is able to accept it.”
Matthew-19-13: Jesus Welcomes Children(B) 13 Then the people brought their little children to Jesus so that he could lay his hands on them to bless them and pray for them. When the followers saw this, they told the people to stop bringing their children to him.
Matthew-19-14: 14 But Jesus said, “Let the little children come to me. Don’t stop them, because God’s kingdom belongs to people who are like these children.”
Matthew-19-15: 15 After Jesus blessed the children, he left there.
Matthew-19-16: A Rich Man Refuses to Follow Jesus(C) 16 A man came to Jesus and asked, “Teacher, what good thing must I do to have eternal life?”
Matthew-19-17: 17 Jesus answered, “Why do you ask me about what is good? Only God is good. But if you want to have eternal life, obey the law’s commands.”
Matthew-19-18: 18 The man asked, “Which ones?” Jesus answered, “‘You must not murder anyone, you must not commit adultery, you must not steal, you must not tell lies about others,
Matthew-19-19: 19 you must respect your father and mother,’[e] and ‘love your neighbor[f] the same as you love yourself.’[g]”
Matthew-19-20: 20 The young man said, “I have obeyed all these commands. What else do I need?”
Matthew-19-21: 21 Jesus answered, “If you want to be perfect, then go and sell all that you own. Give the money to the poor, and you will have riches in heaven. Then come and follow me!”
Matthew-19-22: 22 But when the young man heard Jesus tell him to give away his money, he was sad. He didn’t want to do this, because he was very rich. So he left.
Matthew-19-23: 23 Then Jesus said to his followers, “The truth is, it will be very hard for a rich person to enter God’s kingdom.
Matthew-19-24: 24 Yes, I tell you, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to enter God’s kingdom.”
Matthew-19-25: 25 The followers were amazed to hear this. They asked, “Then who can be saved?”
Matthew-19-26: 26 Jesus looked at them and said, “This is something that people cannot do. But God can do anything.”
Matthew-19-27: 27 Peter said to him, “We left everything we had and followed you. So what will we have?”
Matthew-19-28: 28 Jesus said to them, “When the time of the new world comes, the Son of Man will sit on his great and glorious throne. And I can promise that you who followed me will sit on twelve thrones, and you will judge the twelve tribes of Israel.
Matthew-19-29: 29 Everyone who has left houses, brothers, sisters, father, mother, children, or farms to follow me will get much more than they left. And they will have eternal life.
Matthew-19-30: 30 Many people who are first now will be last in the future. And many who are last now will be first in the future.
Matthew-20-1: Jesus Uses a Story About Farm Workers 20 “God’s kingdom is like a man who owned some land. One morning, the man went out very early to hire some people to work in his vineyard.
Matthew-20-2: 2 He agreed to pay the workers one silver coin for working that day. Then he sent them into the vineyard to work.
Matthew-20-3: 3 “About nine o’clock the man went to the marketplace and saw some other people standing there. They were doing nothing.
Matthew-20-4: 4 So he said to them, ‘If you go and work in my field, I will pay you what your work is worth.’
Matthew-20-5: 5 So they went to work in the vineyard. “The man went out again about twelve o’clock and again at three o’clock. Both times he hired some others to work in his vineyard.
Matthew-20-6: 6 About five o’clock the man went to the marketplace again. He saw some other people standing there. He asked them, ‘Why did you stand here all day doing nothing?’
Matthew-20-7: 7 “They said, ‘No one gave us a job.’ “The man said to them, ‘Then you can go and work in my vineyard.’
Matthew-20-8: 8 “At the end of the day, the owner of the field said to the boss of all the workers, ‘Call the workers and pay them all. Start by paying the last people I hired. Then pay all of them, ending with the ones I hired first.’
Matthew-20-9: 9 “The workers who were hired at five o’clock came to get their pay. Each worker got one silver coin.
Matthew-20-10: 10 Then the workers who were hired first came to get their pay. They thought they would be paid more than the others. But each one of them also received one silver coin.
Matthew-20-11: 11 When they got their silver coin, they complained to the man who owned the land.
Matthew-20-12: 12 They said, ‘Those people were hired last and worked only one hour. But you paid them the same as us. And we worked hard all day in the hot sun.’
Matthew-20-13: 13 “But the man who owned the field said to one of them, ‘Friend, I am being fair with you. You agreed to work for one silver coin. Right?
Matthew-20-14: 14 So take your pay and go. I want to give the man who was hired last the same pay I gave you.
Matthew-20-15: 15 I can do what I want with my own money. Why would you be jealous because I am generous?’
Matthew-20-16: 16 “So those who are last now will be first in the future. And those who are first now will be last in the future.”
Matthew-20-17: Jesus Talks Again About His Death(A) 17 Jesus was going to Jerusalem. His twelve followers were with him. While they were walking, he gathered the followers together and spoke to them privately. He said to them,
Matthew-20-18: 18 “We are going to Jerusalem. The Son of Man will be handed over to the leading priests and the teachers of the law, and they will say he must die.
Matthew-20-19: 19 They will hand him over to the foreigners, who will laugh at him and beat him with whips, and then they will kill him on a cross. But on the third day after his death, he will be raised to life again.”
Matthew-20-20: A Mother Asks a Special Favor(B) 20 Then Zebedee’s wife came to Jesus and brought her sons. She bowed before Jesus and asked him to do something for her.
Matthew-20-21: 21 Jesus said, “What do you want?” She said, “Promise that one of my sons will sit at your right side in your kingdom and the other at your left.”
Matthew-20-22: 22 So Jesus said to the sons, “You don’t understand what you are asking. Can you drink from the cup[a] that I must drink from?” The sons answered, “Yes, we can!”
Matthew-20-23: 23 Jesus said to them, “It is true that you will drink from the cup that I drink from. But it is not for me to say who will sit at my right or my left. My Father has decided who will do that. He has prepared those places for them.”
Matthew-20-24: 24 The other ten followers heard this and were angry with the two brothers.
Matthew-20-25: 25 So Jesus called the followers together. He said, “You know that the rulers of the non-Jewish people love to show their power over the people. And their important leaders love to use all their authority over the people.
Matthew-20-26: 26 But it should not be that way with you. Whoever wants to be your leader must be your servant.
Matthew-20-27: 27 Whoever wants to be first must serve the rest of you like a slave.
Matthew-20-28: 28 Do as I did: The Son of Man did not come for people to serve him. He came to serve others and to give his life to save many people.”
Matthew-20-29: Jesus Heals Two Blind Men(C) 29 When Jesus and his followers were leaving Jericho, a large crowd followed him.
Matthew-20-30: 30 There were two blind men sitting by the road. They heard that Jesus was coming by. So they shouted, “Lord, Son of David, please help us!”
Matthew-20-31: 31 The people there criticized the blind men and told them to be quiet. But they shouted more and more, “Lord, Son of David, please help us!”
Matthew-20-32: 32 Jesus stopped and said to them, “What do you want me to do for you?”
Matthew-20-33: 33 They answered, “Lord, we want to be able to see.”
Matthew-20-34: 34 Jesus felt sorry for the blind men. He touched their eyes, and immediately they were able to see. Then they became followers of Jesus.
Matthew-21-1: Jesus Enters Jerusalem Like a King(A) 21 Jesus and his followers were coming closer to Jerusalem. But first they stopped at Bethphage at the hill called the Mount of Olives. From there Jesus sent two of his followers into town.
Matthew-21-2: 2 He said to them, “Go to the town you can see there. When you enter it, you will find a donkey with her colt. Untie them both, and bring them to me.
Matthew-21-3: 3 If anyone asks you why you are taking the donkeys, tell them, ‘The Master needs them. He will send them back soon.’”
Matthew-21-4: 4 This showed the full meaning of what the prophet said:
Matthew-21-5: 5 “Tell the people of Zion,[a]     ‘Now your king is coming to you. ‘Now your king is coming to you. He is humble and riding on a donkey.     He is riding on a young donkey, born from a work animal.’” (B) He is riding on a young donkey, born from a work animal.’” (B)
Matthew-21-6: 6 The followers went and did what Jesus told them to do.
Matthew-21-7: 7 They brought the mother donkey and the young donkey to him. They covered the donkeys with their coats, and Jesus sat on them.
Matthew-21-8: 8 On the way to Jerusalem, many people spread their coats on the road for Jesus. Others cut branches from the trees and spread them on the road.
Matthew-21-9: 9 Some of the people were walking ahead of Jesus. Others were walking behind him. They all shouted, “Praise[b] to the Son of David!     ‘Welcome! God bless the one who comes in the name of the Lord!’ (C) ‘Welcome! God bless the one who comes in the name of the Lord!’ (C) Praise to God in heaven!”
Matthew-21-10: 10 Then Jesus went into Jerusalem. All the people in the city were confused. They asked, “Who is this man?”
Matthew-21-11: 11 The crowds following Jesus answered, “This is Jesus. He is the prophet from the town of Nazareth in Galilee.”
Matthew-21-12: Jesus Goes to the Temple(D) 12 Jesus went into the Temple area. He threw out all those who were selling and buying things there. He turned over the tables that belonged to those who were exchanging different kinds of money. And he turned over the benches of those who were selling doves.
Matthew-21-13: 13 Jesus said to them, “The Scriptures say, ‘My Temple will be called a house of prayer.’[c] But you are changing it into a ‘hiding place for thieves.’[d]”
Matthew-21-14: 14 Some blind people and some who were crippled came to Jesus in the Temple area. Jesus healed them.
Matthew-21-15: 15 The leading priests and the teachers of the law saw the wonderful things he was doing. And they saw the children praising him in the Temple area. The children were shouting, “Praise to the Son of David.” All this made the priests and the teachers of the law angry.
Matthew-21-16: 16 They asked Jesus, “Do you hear what these children are saying?” He answered, “Yes. The Scriptures say, ‘You have taught children and babies to give praise.’[e] Have you not read that Scripture?”
Matthew-21-17: 17 Then Jesus left them and went out of the city to Bethany, where he spent the night.
Matthew-21-18: Jesus Shows the Power of Faith(E) 18 Early the next morning, Jesus was going back to the city. He was very hungry.
Matthew-21-19: 19 He saw a fig tree beside the road and went to get a fig from it. But there were no figs on the tree. There were only leaves. So Jesus said to the tree, “You will never again produce fruit!” The tree immediately dried up and died.
Matthew-21-20: 20 When the followers saw this, they were very surprised. They asked, “How did the fig tree dry up and die so quickly?”
Matthew-21-21: 21 Jesus answered, “The truth is, if you have faith and no doubts, you will be able to do the same as I did to this tree. And you will be able to do more. You will be able to say to this mountain, ‘Go, mountain, fall into the sea.’ And if you have faith, it will happen.
Matthew-21-22: 22 If you believe, you will get anything you ask for in prayer.”
Matthew-21-23: Jewish Leaders Doubt Jesus’ Authority(F) 23 Jesus went into the Temple area. While Jesus was teaching there, the leading priests and the older leaders of the people came to him. They said, “Tell us! What authority do you have to do these things you are doing? Who gave you this authority?”
Matthew-21-24: 24 Jesus answered, “I will ask you a question too. If you answer me, then I will tell you what authority I have to do these things.
Matthew-21-25: 25 Tell me: When John baptized people, did his authority come from God, or was it only from other people?” The priests and the Jewish leaders talked about Jesus’ question. They said to each other, “If we answer, ‘John’s baptism was from God,’ then he will say, ‘Then why didn’t you believe John?’
Matthew-21-26: 26 But we can’t say John’s baptism was from someone else. We are afraid of the people, because they all believe John was a prophet.”
Matthew-21-27: 27 So they told Jesus, “We don’t know the answer.” Jesus said, “Then I will not tell you who gave me the authority to do these things.
Matthew-21-28: Jesus Uses a Story About Two Sons 28 “Tell me what you think about this: There was a man who had two sons. He went to the first son and said, ‘Son, go and work today in the vineyard.’
Matthew-21-29: 29 “The son answered, ‘I will not go.’ But later he decided he should go, and he went.
Matthew-21-30: 30 “Then the father went to the other son and said, ‘Son, go and work today in the vineyard.’ He answered, ‘Yes, sir, I will go and work.’ But he did not go.
Matthew-21-31: 31 “Which of the two sons obeyed his father?” The Jewish leaders answered, “The first son.” Jesus said to them, “The truth is, you are worse than the tax collectors and the prostitutes. In fact, they will enter God’s kingdom before you enter.
Matthew-21-32: 32 John came showing you the right way to live, and you did not believe him. But the tax collectors and prostitutes believed John. You saw that happening, but you would not change. You still refused to believe him.
Matthew-21-33: God Sends His Son(G) 33 “Listen to this story: There was a man who owned a vineyard. He put a wall around the field and dug a hole for a winepress. Then he built a tower. He leased the land to some farmers and then left on a trip.
Matthew-21-34: 34 Later, it was time for the grapes to be picked. So the man sent his servants to the farmers to get his share of the grapes.
Matthew-21-35: 35 “But the farmers grabbed the servants and beat one. They killed another one and then stoned to death a third servant.
Matthew-21-36: 36 So the man sent some other servants to the farmers. He sent more servants than he sent the first time. But the farmers did the same thing to them that they did the first time.
Matthew-21-37: 37 So the man decided to send his son to the farmers. He said, ‘The farmers will respect my son.’
Matthew-21-38: 38 “But when the farmers saw the son, they said to each other, ‘This is the owner’s son. This vineyard will be his. If we kill him, it will be ours.’
Matthew-21-39: 39 So the farmers took the son, threw him out of the vineyard, and killed him.
Matthew-21-40: 40 “So what will the owner of the vineyard do to these farmers when he comes?”
Matthew-21-41: 41 The Jewish priests and leaders said, “He will surely kill those evil men. Then he will lease the land to other farmers, who will give him his share of the crop at harvest time.”
Matthew-21-42: 42 Jesus said to them, “Surely you have read this in the Scriptures: ‘The stone that the builders refused to accept     became the cornerstone. became the cornerstone. The Lord did this,     and it is wonderful to us.’ (H) and it is wonderful to us.’ (H)
Matthew-21-43: 43 “So I tell you that God’s kingdom will be taken away from you. It will be given to people who do what God wants in his kingdom.
Matthew-21-44: 44 Whoever falls on this stone will be broken. And it will crush anyone it falls on.”[f]
Matthew-21-45: 45 When the leading priests and the Pharisees heard these stories, they knew that Jesus was talking about them.
Matthew-21-46: 46 They wanted to find a way to arrest Jesus. But they were afraid to do anything, because the people believed that Jesus was a prophet.
Matthew-22-1: A Story About People Invited to a Dinner(A) 22 Jesus used some more stories to teach the people. He said,
Matthew-22-2: 2 “God’s kingdom is like a king who prepared a wedding feast for his son.
Matthew-22-3: 3 He invited some people to the feast. When it was ready, the king sent his servants to tell the people to come. But they refused to come to the king’s feast.
Matthew-22-4: 4 “Then the king sent some more servants. He said to them, ‘I have already invited the people. So tell them that my feast is ready. I have killed my best bulls and calves to be eaten. Everything is ready. Come to the wedding feast.’
Matthew-22-5: 5 “But when the servants told the people to come, they refused to listen. They all went to do other things. One went to work in his field, and another went to his business.
Matthew-22-6: 6 Some of the other people grabbed the servants, beat them, and killed them.
Matthew-22-7: 7 The king was very angry. He sent his army to kill those who murdered his servants. And the army burned their city.
Matthew-22-8: 8 “After that the king said to his servants, ‘The wedding feast is ready. I invited those people, but they were not good enough to come to my feast.
Matthew-22-9: 9 So go to the street corners and invite everyone you see. Tell them to come to my feast.’
Matthew-22-10: 10 So the servants went into the streets. They gathered all the people they could find, good and bad alike, and brought them to where the wedding feast was ready. And the place was filled with guests.

Matthew-26-1: The Jewish Leaders Plan to Kill Jesus(A) 26 After Jesus finished saying all these things, he said to his followers,
Matthew-26-2: 2 “You know that the day after tomorrow is Passover. On that day the Son of Man will be handed over to his enemies to be killed on a cross.”
Matthew-26-3: 3 Then the leading priests and the older Jewish leaders had a meeting at the palace where the high priest lived. The high priest’s name was Caiaphas.

Matthew-26-5: 5 They said, “We cannot arrest Jesus during Passover. We don’t want the people to become angry and cause a riot.”
Matthew-26-6: A Woman Does Something Special(B) 6 Jesus was in Bethany at the house of Simon the leper.
Matthew-26-7: 7 While he was there, a woman came to him. She had an alabaster jar filled with expensive perfume. She poured the perfume on Jesus’ head while he was eating.
Matthew-26-8: 8 The followers saw the woman do this and were upset at her. They said, “Why waste that perfume?
Matthew-26-9: 9 It could be sold for a lot of money, and the money could be given to those who are poor.”
Matthew-26-10: 10 But Jesus knew what happened. He said, “Why are you bothering this woman? She did a very good thing for me.

Matthew-26-12: 12 This woman poured perfume on my body. She did this to prepare me for burial after I die.
Matthew-26-13: 13 The Good News will be told to people all over the world. And I can assure you that everywhere the Good News is told, the story of what this woman did will also be told, and people will remember her.”
